SafetyInspectionBy: MI Inspection done by Industrial Consultants

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

DOT Foods, Inc., founded in 1960, is the largest food redistributor in the United States serving distributors coast to coast on a daily basis. Headquartered in Mt. Sterling, Illinois, DOT is a family owned business that has grown from a single station wagon driven by the founder, Robert Tracy, to a fleet of over 400 multi-temp tractor trailers. This growth is in large part due to the customer driven attitude that is exhibited by all the members of the DOT team.  As stated on their website, DOT Foods will continue to be driven by the values of integrity, growth, profit, and customer satisfaction, with emphasis on innovation and employee welfare.

DOT Foods, Inc., located in Williamsport, Maryland, provides refrigeration for warehousing and distribution of food and related products and services. DOT Foods, Inc.senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but also maintains a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. DOT Foods, Inc. administers safety and environmental policies at the facility to ensure compliance with OSHA¿s Process Safety Management (PSM) and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP). These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, employee safety manuals, manufacturers¿ documentation, and the Emergency Response Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

DOT Foods, Inc. is located at 16301 Elliot Parkway in Williamsport, Maryland.  The facility is approximately one mile south of Interstate 70 and approximately 400 feet north of the Western Maryland Railway.  The area surrounding the facility is rural with a mixture of light business and residential areas. 

The refrigeration systems were designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations.

The facility's system uses a total of 17,999 pounds of ammonia to

provide refrigeration for warehousing and distribution of food and related products and services. The ammonia refrigeration system uses 17,999 pounds of ammonia for dock operations, warehouse cold storage, and freezer storage.  The majority of the system is located in the machine room including vessels and compressors.  The condensers are mounted on the machine room roof and all of the evaporators are located in their respective cold storage rooms/areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The DOT Foods, Inc. facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.  These safety features include ammonia sensors in the machine room as well as sensors in selected cold storage areas, and automatic shut down systems.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the machine room or on the machine room roof (condensers). 

Ammonia sensors are present in the machine room and cold storage areas.  The system shuts down if a concentration of 20,000 ppm is detected in the machine room and 35ppm in the cold storage areas.  The operators have the ability to dial into the central computer and read the alarm from a portable computer.  

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the DOT Foods, Inc. - Williamsport facility's accident history revealed that there have been no reportable ammonia releases (> 100 pounds) over the past five years.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

DOT Foods, Inc.  Has an emergency response plan in effect at

the facility.   The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM document, which is maintained at the facility. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

¿     To save lives.
¿     To minimize and avoid injuries.
¿     To protect the environment.
¿     To minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility caused by an ammonia release.  The facility maintains a safety committee (a trained Emergency Response team) whose members are designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The emergency response team is trained to call 9-1-1 in an event of an ammonia release. The 9-1-1 operator will contact the local HAZMAT team and the local Fire and Rescue Squad.  The operators also have the ability to dial into the central computer (M&M Computer Control System) and read the alarm from a portable computer.  Ammonia sensors are present in the machine room and cold storage areas.  The system shuts down if a concentration of 20,000 ppm is detected in the machine room and 35ppm in the cold storage areas.  During off-hours, the alarm is directed to an outside alarm company that informs the on-call operator.  

Employees within the building are evacuated to a point upwind of the facility or shelter in place.  Evacuation drills are performed quarterly.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) performed in October 11, 2007 and the PHA Revalidation performed in March 29, 2012, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the DOT Foods, Inc. facility loc

ated at 16301 Elliot Parkway, Williamsport, Maryland.  The scheduled completion date of all changes resulting from the PHA Revalidation is 3-29-13.  In the meantime, DOT Foods, Inc. safety committee has completed several items, including the recommendations, in a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
